": { "definition": "

The administration of succinylcholine, a depolarizing neuromuscular
blocker, can cause a transient but potentially life-threatening hyperkalemia, not hypercalcemia. This

effect is exaggerated in patients with certain underlying conditions.

", "atAGlance": "
  • Mechanism
of Hyperkalemia: Succinylcholine is an acetylcholine receptor agonist. Its binding to nicotinic receptors on the motor

endplate causes a sustained depolarization, which leads to an efflux of potassium (K+) from muscle cells.
  • Normal
Response: In healthy individuals, this results in a small, clinically insignificant rise in serum K+ (approx

. 0.5 mEq/L).
  • Exaggerated Response: In patients with upregulation of acetylcholine
receptors (e.g., burns, crush injuries, denervating injuries, myopathies), succinylcholine can cause a massive K

+ release, leading to severe, life-threatening hyperkalemia and cardiac arrest.
  • Hyper
calcemia Note: Succinylcholine is a trigger for [[429af8bd|malignant hyperther
mia]], a condition involving massive release of calcium from the sarcoplasmic reticulum, but it does not directly cause serum

hypercalcemia. The primary electrolyte concern with succinylcholine itself is hyperkalemia.
  • USMLE Tip: Succ
inylcholine is contraindicated in patients with major burns, crush injuries, or upper motor neuron disease due to the risk of severe

hyperkalemia.", "takeAway": "

Succinylcholine's depolarizing action at
the neuromuscular junction invariably causes a potassium efflux from muscle cells; while normally benign, this effect becomes dangerously amplified in conditions with receptor

p>Hypercoagulability, whether inherited or acquired, is a major risk factor for the development of

dural venous sinus thrombosis (DVST), a condition involving clot formation in the venous sinuses that drain blood from the brain.

",

"atAGlance": "
  • Dural Venous Sinus Thrombosis (DVST): A type
of stroke caused by thrombosis of the dural venous sinuses. This obstructs venous drainage, leading to venous congestion, increased intracranial pressure, and potentially

venous infarction or hemorrhage.
  • Hypercoagulable States: Conditions that predispose to thrombosis are a key

cause of DVST, especially in younger patients without other stroke risk factors.
  • Inherited Hypercoagulability: Includes

Factor V Leiden mutation, prothrombin gene mutation, and deficiencies of antithrombin, protein C, or protein S.
  • Acquired Hyper
coagulability: Includes pregnancy/puerperium, oral contraceptive use, malignancy, and antiphospholipid syndrome.
• Clinical Presentation of DVST: Often presents with a severe headache, but can also cause seizures, focal neurological

deficits, and signs of increased ICP like [[4ae219da|papilledema]].
  • USMLE Tip: In
a young patient, especially a woman who is pregnant or taking oral contraceptives, who presents with a severe headache and/or stroke
-like symptoms, dural venous sinus thrombosis due to a hypercoagulable state should be a top consideration.", "take

Away": "

While arterial strokes are often linked to atherosclerosis, dural venous sinus thrombosis is frequently
a manifestation of an underlying hypercoagulable state, making a hematologic workup essential in patients presenting with this

"content": { "definition": "

Hyperopia, commonly known as farsightedness, is a
refractive error of the eye in which parallel light rays from distant objects are focused behind the retina, causing near

objects to appear blurry.

", "atAGlance": "
  • Pathophysiology: Occ
urs when the eye is either too short (axial hyperopia) or the cornea/lens system has too little refractive power (ref

ractive hyperopia).
  • Clinical Presentation: Patients can see distant objects clearly but have difficulty with near-vision tasks like

reading. Young patients may be able to compensate by accommodating, but this can lead to eye strain and headaches.
  • Correction
: Corrected with a convex (converging) lens (e.g., glasses
or contact lenses with a positive diopter prescription). The converging lens adds refractive power, moving the focal point forward onto the retina.
• Distinction from Presbyopia: While both cause blurry near vision, hyperopia is a refractive error present
from a young age, whereas [[767d985e|presbyopia]] is an age-related loss of accommodation.
• USMLE Tip: Remember the correction: Hyperopia (farsightedness) is corrected with a

convex lens.", "takeAway": "

Hyperopia is a refractive
error where the eye's focusing power is insufficient for its length, causing near images to be focused behind the retina. This

      "Pit
actinemia is a condition of elevated serum prolactin levels, which can be caused by physiological states, medications, or pathological

conditions such as a prolactin-secreting pituitary adenoma (prolactinoma).

", "atAGlance": "
Physiology: Prolactin secretion from the anterior pituitary is tonically inhibited by [[90adc821|dopamine]] from

the hypothalamus (via the tuberoinfundibular pathway).
  • Prolactinoma: The most common type

of functional [[5f3188bd|pituitary adenoma]]. It autonomously secretes prolactin.
  • Drug
-Induced: Many drugs can cause hyperprolactinemia by blocking dopamine's inhibitory effect. These include most

antipsychotics (dopamine D2 receptor antagonists) and metoclopramide.
  • Clinical
Presentation (Women): Galactorrhea (milky nipple discharge), amenorrhea, and infertility (as high prolactin inhibits

GnRH release).
  • Clinical Presentation (Men): Decreased libido, impotence, and gynecomastia.
  • Treatment
: The first-line treatment for prolactinomas is a dopamine agonist (e.g.,

cabergoline, bromocriptine), which shrinks the tumor and normalizes prolactin levels.
  • USMLE Tip: Any
drug that blocks dopamine receptors can cause hyperprolactinemia and its associated symptoms. This is a common side effect of antipsych

otic medications.", "takeAway": "

Hyperprolactinemia is most
often a result of either a prolactin-secreting tumor or a disruption of the normal dopaminergic inhibition of the pituitary

, leading to a classic triad of galactorrhea, amenorrhea, and infertility.

ohyalinosis. This weakens the vessel walls, leading to the formation of <mark>Charcot-Bouchard micro

aneurysms.
  • Mechanism of Bleed: Rupture of these microaneurysms is the primary cause

of hypertensive intraparenchymal hemorrhage.
  • Common Locations: The bleeds typically occur in deep brain structures supplied
by these small penetrating arteries. The most common sites, in order of frequency, are the <mark>basal ganglia (

putamen), thalamus, pons, and cerebellum.
  • Clinical Presentation: Sudden onset of focal

neurological deficits that progress over minutes to hours, often accompanied by headache, vomiting, and signs of increased ICP.
  • USMLE Tip:
An elderly patient with a history of poorly controlled hypertension who presents with a sudden focal deficit and signs of increased ICP has
likely suffered a hypertensive intraparenchymal hemorrhage, most probably in the basal ganglia.", "

of fragile Charcot-Bouchard microaneurysms that are prone to rupture, causing devastating intraparenchymal hemorrh

p>Hypertensive retinopathy is retinal vascular damage caused by chronically elevated systemic blood pressure. The severity of the findings

on funduscopic examination often correlates with the severity and duration of the hypertension.

", "atAGlance": "
  • Path
ophysiology: Chronic hypertension causes progressive arteriosclerosis of the retinal vessels. This leads to vessel wall thickening, narrowing of

the lumen, and breakdown of the blood-retinal barrier.
  • Funduscopic Findings (Mild to Moderate):

- Arteriolar narrowing (copper wiring, silver wiring).
- Arteriovenous (AV
) nicking</mark>: Venules appear to be compressed or 'nicked' where they are crossed by sclerotic arterioles.<

br> - Flame-shaped hemorrhages and cotton-wool spots.
  • Funduscopic Findings (Severe/

Malignant Hypertension):
- Hard exudates, often arranged in a star pattern around the macula (<

mark>macular star).
- Papilledema (optic

disc swelling), which indicates hypertensive emergency.
  • Clinical Significance: The presence of hypertensive retinopathy is a marker for

systemic end-organ damage from hypertension and is associated with an increased risk of stroke, myocardial infarction, and death.
  • USMLE Tip:
AV nicking is a classic funduscopic finding of chronic hypertension. The presence of papilledema in a hypertensive patient is a sign of malignant

hypertension and is a medical emergency.", "takeAway": "

Hypertensive retinopathy provides
a direct window into the systemic effects of high blood pressure; the changes seen in the retinal arterioles, from AV nicking to pap

illedema, mirror the vascular damage occurring in the kidneys, heart, and brain.

manifestation and the leading cause of death in patients with Friedreich Ataxia, a progressive neurodegenerative disorder.

",

"atAGlance": "
  • Friedreich Ataxia: An autosomal recessive trinucleotide repeat (GAA) disorder

in the frataxin gene, leading to mitochondrial dysfunction.
  • Cardiac Involvement: Occurs in over 90% of

patients with Friedreich Ataxia. Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy is the most common pattern, characterized by concentric left ventricular hypertrophy.
  • Path

ophysiology: Frataxin deficiency leads to mitochondrial iron accumulation and oxidative stress, which damages cardiomyocytes, causing fibrosis and hypertrophy.
  • Clinical
Presentation: Patients may be asymptomatic or present with dyspnea, chest pain, palpitations, or syncope. It

is a major cause of mortality, often due to heart failure or arrhythmias.
  • USMLE Tip: The
combination of neurological symptoms (ataxia, loss of reflexes) and hypertrophic cardiomyopathy in a young patient is highly suggestive of Fried

reich Ataxia.", "takeAway": "

The development of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy is
an integral and life-limiting component of Friedreich Ataxia, demonstrating that the mitochondrial dysfunction caused by frataxin deficiency is

a multisystem disorder that severely impacts high-energy organs like the heart and brain.

      "Pharmac
ilation is a temporary measure used to acutely lower increased intracranial pressure (ICP) by inducing respiratory alkalosis, which causes

cerebral vasoconstriction.

", "atAGlance": "
  • Mechanism of Action: Increased ventilation
(hyperventilation) 'blows off' CO<sub>2</sub>, leading to a decrease in arterial PCO<sub>2</sub> (hypocap
nia). Cerebral blood flow is highly sensitive to PCO<sub>2</sub>. Hypocapnia causes cerebral <mark>vasoconstriction</mark>.
• Effect on ICP: Cerebral vasoconstriction reduces cerebral blood volume, which, according to the Monro-Kell

ie doctrine, leads to a rapid decrease in intracranial pressure.
  • Clinical Use: Used as a temporizing,
life-saving measure in patients with acutely elevated ICP and signs of impending brain herniation (e.g., from severe

traumatic brain injury or large intracranial hemorrhage).
  • Limitations: The effect is transient (lasts for hours). Prolong
ed or excessive hyperventilation can be harmful, as the severe vasoconstriction may lead to cerebral ischemia. It is a

bridge to more definitive treatments (e.g., surgical decompression, osmotic therapy).
  • USMLE Tip: Remember the
relationship: ‚ÜìPCO<sub>2</sub> ‚Üí Vasoconstriction ‚Üí ‚ÜìCerebral Blood Flow ‚Üí ‚ÜìICP. This

is a key physiological principle in neurocritical care.", "takeAway": "

Therapeutic hyperventilation is a
powerful but temporary tool to combat dangerously high intracranial pressure, working by manipulating the potent effect of CO<sub>2</sub> on cerebral

blood vessel tone to rapidly reduce intracranial blood volume.

definition": "

The Hypoglossal Nerve (CN XII) is a purely motor cranial nerve that provides
motor innervation to all the intrinsic and extrinsic muscles of the tongue, except for the palatoglossus (which is innervated by the vag

us nerve).

", "atAGlance": "
  • Function: Controls tongue movement, which is essential

for speech articulation, swallowing, and manipulating food.
  • Origin: Arises from the hypoglossal nucleus in

the medulla and exits the skull through the hypoglossal canal.
  • Lesion Effects (LMN): A
lower motor neuron lesion of CN XII (affecting the nerve itself or its nucleus) causes ipsilateral tongue paralysis. On
protrusion, the tongue will <mark>deviate toward the side of the lesion</mark> due to the unopposed action of the contralateral

genioglossus muscle. Fasciculations and atrophy of the ipsilateral tongue will also be present.
  • Lesion Effects (UMN
): An upper motor neuron lesion (e.g., from a stroke) causes contralateral tongue weakness. On protrusion, the tongue will deviate

away from the side of the cortical lesion.
  • USMLE Tip: Remember the tongue deviation rule: L
MN lesions cause the tongue to 'lick the wound' (deviate toward the lesion). UMN lesions cause the tongue to

deviate away from the lesion.", "takeAway": "

The Hypoglossal Nerve
is the primary driver of tongue movement, and the direction of tongue deviation upon protrusion is a classic and reliable sign for differentiating

between an ipsilateral lower motor neuron lesion and a contralateral upper motor neuron lesion.

", "mermaid": ""

atitis.", "takeAway": "

-threatening conditions where increased intracranial pressure forces brain tissue from one compartment into another, across rigid dural structures like the fal

cus (medial temporal lobe) herniates across the tentorium cerebelli. Classically compresses CN III, causing

content": { "definition": "

Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV) is a neuro
tropic virus that can cause several neurological conditions, most notably a severe, focal encephalitis. HSV-1 is the most common cause

of sporadic encephalitis in the US, while HSV-2 is a common cause of viral meningitis.

", "at

AGlance": "
  • HSV-1 Encephalitis: Has a characteristic predilection for the <
mark>temporal lobes</mark>. Presents with fever, headache, altered mental status, seizures, and focal neurological deficits (e.g., a
phasia). Can lead to [[c6292526|Kl√ºver-Bucy syndrome

]] if bilateral temporal lobes are damaged.
  • HSV-2 Meningitis: A common cause of recurrent aseptic

(viral) meningitis.
  • Bell's Palsy: Reactivation of HSV-1 is the presumed cause of most
cases of Bell's palsy, a peripheral [[a1a54523|facial nerve (CN VII) palsy]].

Diagnosis: PCR of the CSF for HSV DNA is the gold standard for diagnosis of CNS infection.
  • Treatment: Int
ravenous <mark>acyclovir</mark> is the treatment of choice and should be started empirically in any patient with suspected HSV encephalitis

.
  • USMLE Tip: A patient with fever, confusion, seizures, and an MRI showing temporal lobe enhancement
has HSV encephalitis until proven otherwise. Start acyclovir immediately.", "takeAway": "
Herpes Simplex Virus has a distinct neurotropism, with HSV-1 targeting the temporal lobes to cause a devastating
encephalitis, and HSV-2 more commonly causing a self-limited meningitis, both of which are treatable with acyclovir

": { "definition": "

The Hippocampus is a complex brain structure embedded deep
in the medial temporal lobe. It is a major component of the [[73ace357|limbic system]]

and plays a critical role in the consolidation of information from short-term memory to long-term memory, and in spatial navigation.

", "

atAGlance": "
  • Function: Essential for the formation of new declarative (explicit) memories (facts

and events).
  • Lesion Effects: Bilateral damage to the hippocampus results in profound anter
ograde amnesia</mark>, the inability to form new long-term memories. Remote memories and procedural memory (skills

) are typically preserved.
  • Pathology: The hippocampus is one of the first regions of the brain to be affected in
[[77ae6148|Alzheimer disease]], which explains why memory loss is an early symptom. It is also highly

vulnerable to hypoxic-ischemic injury.
  • Limbic System: It is a key part of the Pape

z circuit, connecting to the [[f02cfaa1|mammillary bodies]] via the fornix.
  • US
MLE Tip: The classic case of H.M., who had his hippocampi surgically removed to treat epilepsy, demonstrated

the hippocampus's crucial role in forming new memories.", "takeAway": "

The
Hippocampus acts as the brain's memory 'save button,' crucial for converting the experiences of the
present moment into lasting declarative memories; its destruction leads to a state of being permanently stuck in the past, unable to form new personal

": { "definition": "

Histamine H1 receptors are G-protein coupled receptors that
play a significant role in the central pathways of nausea and vomiting, particularly in the context of motion sickness.

They are a key target for certain antiemetic drugs.

", "atAGlance": "
  • Location
: H1 receptors involved in emesis are located in the vestibular nuclei and the nucleus

tractus solitarius (NTS) in the brainstem.
  • Role in Motion Sickness: The vestibular
system detects motion and sends signals to the vestibular nuclei. This pathway, which involves both H1 and M1 muscarinic receptors, then
projects to the [[74b651ab|vomiting center]] (which includes the NTS).
Pharmacology (Antihistamines): First-generation H1 receptor antagonists (e.g., diphenhydramine, dim
enhydrinate, meclizine) are effective in preventing and treating [[511db4d8
|motion sickness]]. Their efficacy is due to their ability to cross the blood-brain barrier and block central H1 receptors. They

also have significant anticholinergic effects, which contribute to their antiemetic action.
  • USMLE Tip: For
[[511db4d8|motion sickness]], the key neurotransmitters to block are acetylcholine (M1) and histamine (H1).
This is why both scopolamine (antimuscarinic) and first-generation antihistamines are effective.", "

takeAway": "

Histamine H1 receptors in the brainstem are a crucial link in the pathway

from the vestibular system to the vomiting center, making their blockade by first-generation antihistamines an effective strategy for combating motion sickness.

", "

also known as AIDS dementia complex, is a subcortical dementia that occurs in the late stages of HIV infection, characterized by cognitive

, motor, and behavioral abnormalities.

", "atAGlance": "
  • Etiology: Ca
used by the HIV virus infecting CNS cells, primarily <mark>microglia and macrophages</mark>. Neurons are not directly infected but
are damaged by inflammatory cytokines and viral proteins (e.g., gp120, Tat) released by infected glial

cells.
  • Risk Factors: Occurs in patients with advanced immunosuppression, typically with a CD4 count <

200 cells/mm¬≥.
  • Histopathology: The pathognomonic finding is the presence of
<mark>multinucleated giant cells</mark> (formed by the fusion of infected microglia) and microglial nodules in the white

matter and deep gray matter structures.
  • Clinical Presentation: A subcortical dementia, it presents with cognitive
slowing (bradyphrenia), memory problems, apathy, and social withdrawal. Motor symptoms include ataxia, poor balance, and tremors

.
  • Treatment: The incidence and severity of HAD have dramatically decreased with the advent of effective antiretroviral therapy (ART).
• USMLE Tip: The presence of multinucleated giant cells in the brain of an AIDS patient with dementia

is the classic histological finding for HAD.", "takeAway": "

      "Brain
encephaly is a severe congenital brain malformation resulting from the failure of the embryonic forebrain (prosencephalon) to divide

into two distinct cerebral hemispheres during early gestation (weeks 3-4).

", "atAGlance": "
  • Path
ophysiology: A developmental field defect involving incomplete cleavage of the prosencephalon. It is associated with mutations in genes

involved in the Sonic hedgehog (SHH) signaling pathway.
  • Spectrum of Severity: Ranges
from alobar (most severe, single ventricle and no hemispheric separation) to semilobar and lobar (less

severe).
  • Associated Midline Facial Defects: The severity of the brain malformation often correlates with the severity of midline
facial defects. These can range from a single maxillary incisor or cleft lip/palate to severe anomalies like cyclopia (

a single eye).
  • Associated Conditions: Can be seen in genetic syndromes like Patau syndrome (Trisomy 1

3) and as a feature of fetal alcohol syndrome.
  • USMLE Tip: The combination of a severe midline
facial defect (like cyclopia or a single nostril) and a major brain malformation is characteristic of holoprosencephaly.

Think of SHH pathway mutations and Trisomy 13.", "takeAway": "

Holopros
encephaly is a fundamental failure of the brain to divide into left and right hemispheres, a process intimately linked to the development of the midline

face, such that the 'face predicts the brain'‚Äîsevere facial anomalies often signal an underlying undivided brain.

      "General
process by which biological systems maintain a stable internal environment despite changes in external conditions. The hypothalamus is the

primary control center for maintaining homeostasis in the body.

", "atAGlance": "
  • Hyp
othalamic Function: The [[89e86633|hypothalamus]] acts as a

thermostat and regulator, monitoring and controlling numerous physiological parameters to keep them within a narrow range.
  • Parameters Regulated: Key

homeostatic functions controlled by the hypothalamus include:
- Temperature Regulation: Anterior hypothalamus for cooling, posterior for

heating.
- Water Balance: Osmoreceptors trigger thirst and ADH release.
-

Energy Balance: Lateral nucleus for hunger, ventromedial for satiety.
- Autonomic Control

: Regulates both sympathetic and parasympathetic output.
- Endocrine Function: Controls the pituitary gland.
• Feedback Loops: Homeostasis is maintained through negative feedback loops, where a change in a variable triggers a response that counter

acts the initial change.
  • USMLE Tip: Many questions in physiology and endocrinology are based on understanding the home

ostatic feedback loops controlled by the hypothalamus.", "takeAway": "

The hypothalamus is the master
coordinator of homeostasis, acting like a sophisticated control panel that constantly adjusts the body's autonomic, endocrine

": { "definition": "

Homer-Wright rosettes are a characteristic histological finding in several
small round blue cell tumors, where tumor cells arrange themselves in a circular pattern around a central space filled with fibrillary material (

neuropil).

", "atAGlance": "
  • Appearance: A ring of small

, dark tumor cell nuclei surrounding a central, eosinophilic, fibrillary core that is devoid of a blood vessel or lumen.
  • Associated

Tumors: They are a classic feature of several neuroblastic tumors, including:
- Medulloblastoma</

mark>: The most common malignant pediatric brain tumor.
- Neuroblastoma: A common extrac

ranial solid tumor of childhood, arising from neural crest cells.
- Pineoblastoma and Ewing sarcoma (less commonly

).
  • Distinction from Other Rosettes:
    - Flexner-Wintersteiner ro

settes: Have a true central lumen; seen in retinoblastoma.
- Perivascular pseud

orosettes: Tumor cells are arranged around a central blood vessel; seen in ependymomas.
  • USMLE Tip:
The presence of Homer-Wright rosettes in a cerebellar tumor from a child is pathognomonic for [[16d

613bb|medulloblastoma]].", "takeAway": "

Homer-Wright rosettes
are a histological sign of primitive neuroblastic differentiation, where undifferentiated tumor cells attempt to form a rudimentary synapse-

like structure, creating a distinctive circular pattern that is a key diagnostic feature of tumors like medulloblastoma and neuroblastoma.

", "mermaid

      "Anatomy and Physiology",
Homunculus (Latin for \"little man\") is a distorted, topographic representation of the human body located in the primary
motor cortex and the primary somatosensory cortex. The disproportionate size of body parts in the homunculus reflects the density

of innervation and functional importance of those areas.

", "atAGlance": "
  • Motor Homunculus: Located
in the precentral gyrus (frontal lobe). Represents the origin of the corticospinal tracts. Areas with fine motor control,

like the hands and face, have a very large representation.
  • Sensory Homunculus: Located in the
postcentral gyrus (parietal lobe). Represents the termination of sensory pathways. Areas with high tactile sensitivity, like the <mark>lips

and fingertips, have a very large representation.
  • Somatotopic Arrangement: The body is represented
in an upside-down and inverted fashion. The feet and legs are located on the medial surface of the hemisphere, while the trunk

, arm, hand, and face are located along the lateral convexity.
  • Vascular Supply and Clinical Correlation: This

arrangement is clinically significant for localizing strokes:
- Anterior Cerebral Artery (ACA) stroke

: Affects the medial cortex, causing contralateral leg and foot deficits.
- Middle Cerebral Artery (MCA) stroke:</

mark> Affects the lateral cortex, causing contralateral face and arm deficits.
  • USMLE Tip: The vascular

supply of the homunculus is a very high-yield concept for stroke localization questions.", "takeAway": "

The
Homunculus is a neural map that illustrates the brain's prioritization of function over physical size, with the vast

cortical real estate devoted to the hands and face underscoring their critical roles in motor dexterity and sensory perception.

",

": "

A hordeolum, commonly known as a stye, is an acute, painful

, purulent inflammation of an eyelid gland, typically caused by a bacterial infection.

", "atAGlance": "
  • Types

:
- External Hordeolum: An infection of a sebaceous gland of Zeis or

an apocrine gland of Moll, located at the eyelid margin. This is the more common type.
- Internal Hordeol
um: An infection of a meibomian gland, located within the tarsal plate of the eyelid.

• Etiology: Most commonly caused by an infection with Staphylococcus aureus.
  • Clinical Presentation
: A localized, painful, red, swollen lump on or within the eyelid. It

may have a central point of pus (pustule).
  • Treatment: The mainstay of treatment is warm compresses to

promote drainage. Topical antibiotics may be used. Incision and drainage may be required if it does not resolve.
  • Distinction from Chal
azion: A [[chalazion]] is a granulomatous inflammation of a meibomian gland, not an acute
infection. It is typically <mark>painless</mark>, harder, and located further from the eyelid margin than an

external hordeolum.
  • USMLE Tip: The key differentiating feature between a hordeolum and a chalazion is pain
. Hordeolum = Hurts. Chalazion = Chronic and non-tender

.", "takeAway": "

A hordeolum is essentially a
small abscess of an eyelid gland, presenting as a tender, red bump, which distinguishes it from the painless, chronic granulomatous nod

ule of a chalazion.

us]], which integrates peripheral hormonal signals from the gut and adipose tissue with central neuronal circuits to control food intake and energy expenditure

.

", "atAGlance": "

us: The hunger center. Stimulation induces hunger. It is inhibited by leptin and stimulated by ghrelin. Lesion

>. Stimulation induces satiety. It is stimulated by leptin. Lesion ‚Üí hyperphagia and obesity.

Secreted by adipose tissue; signals satiety (long-term).

stomach; stimulates hunger (short-term).

; signals satiety.

ean (lesion). Ventromedial nucleus makes you Very M

": { "definition": "

Huntington Disease is an autosomal dominant neurodegenerative disorder characterized by
a triad of motor, cognitive, and psychiatric symptoms, caused by an expansion of a CAG trinucleotide repeat in the huntingtin

(HTT) gene.

", "atAGlance": "
  • Genetics: Aut
osomal dominant inheritance with <mark>anticipation</mark> (disease becomes more severe and appears at an earlier age in successive
generations). Caused by a CAG trinucleotide repeat expansion on chromosome 4. Mnemonic: Caud

ate loses ACh and GABA.
  • Pathophysiology: Degeneration of GABA
ergic neurons in the <mark>caudate and putamen</mark> (striatum). This leads to atrophy

of the striatum, visible on imaging as enlargement of the lateral ventricles.
  • Neurotransmitter Changes: Marked
decrease in [[5aa5cb91|GABA]] and [[6a005559|acetylcholine]],

with a relative excess of [[90adc821|dopamine]].
  • Clinical Presentation: On
set typically between ages 30-50. Presents with <mark>chorea</mark> (involuntary, dance

-like movements), progressing to dementia and psychiatric disturbances (depression, aggression).
  • Treatment: There is no cure.
Symptomatic treatment for chorea includes dopamine antagonists (e.g., haloperidol) or VMAT inhibitors (e.g., tetr

abenazine).
  • USMLE Tip: A patient in their 40s with new-onset chorea and personality
changes should make you think of Huntington disease. The key pathology is atrophy of the caudate nucleus.", "take

Away": "

Huntington Disease is a fatal genetic disorder where an expanded CAG repeat leads to the progressive destruction of GABA
ergic neurons in the striatum, resulting in a devastating clinical triad of uncontrollable movements (chorea), cognitive decline (dementia), and psychiatric illness

.
